issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the status of the assessee, Seth Govindram Sugar Mills, Mahidpur Road, Proprietor Nandlal Bachhulal, Jaora, is an Association of Persons or a firm within the meaning of Section 16(1)(b) of the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the order of the Appellate Tribunal is illegal on account of the Tribunal having committed an error of record and having omitted to consider the relevant material in the case. The High Court, for reasons given in its judgment, held on the first question that in the assessment year 1949-50 the status of the assessee was that of a firm within the meaning of s. 16 1 , b  of the Income-tax Act and on the second question it held

issues.text: whether during the assessment year 1950-51 the assessee was a firm or an association of persons.

anchor.surface_text: held by the High Court against the appellant. Indeed, the only effective question is whether during the assessment year 1950-51 the assesee was a firm or an association of persons. The first question raised by the learned Attorney General is that on the death of Nandlal the firm of Seth Govindram Sugar Mills was dissolved and thereafter the income of the said business could only be assessed as that of an association of persons.

issues.text: whether on the death of Nandlal his heirs, i.e., the members of his branch of the family, automatically became partners of the said firm.

anchor.surface_text: Under cl.  3  of the partnership deed, The death of any of the parties shall not dissolve the partnership and either the legal heir or the nominee of the deceased partner shall take his place in the provisions of the partnership The question is whether on the death of Nandlal his heirs, i.e., the members of his branch of the family, automatically became

issues.text: whether the widow of Nandlal could under Hindu law be a karta of the joint Hindu family consisting of three widows and two minors.

anchor.surface_text: One is whether the widow of Nandlal could under Hindu law be a karta of the joint Hindu family consisting of three widows and two minors. There is conflict of view on this question. The Nagpur High Court held that a widow could be a karta see Commissioner of Income-tax, C. P. Berar v. Seth Laxmi Narayan Raghunathdas 1  Pandurang Dahke Pandurang Gorle 2 , The Calcutta High Court expressed the view that where the male members are minors and their natural guardian is the mother, the mother can represent the Hindu undivided family for the purpose of assessment and recovery of taxes under the Income-tax Act see Sushila Devi Rampurla v. Income-tax Officer 2  and  3   1959  38 I.T.R. 316.

issues.text: whether after the death of Nandlal a new partnership was entered into between the representatives of the two branches of the families, i.e., Nandlals and Bachhulals.

anchor.surface_text: The question, therefore, is whether after the death of Nandlal the representatives of the two families constituted a new partnership and carried on the business of the Sugar Mills. Admittedly no fresh partnership deed was executed between Banarsibai, acting as the guardian of the minors in Nandlals branch of the family and Bachhulal. It is not disputed that partnership between the representatives of two families can be inferred from conduct.

arguments.claim: On the death of Nandlal the firm of Seth Govindram Sugar Mills was dissolved and thereafter the income of the said business could only be assessed as that of an association of persons.

arguments.court_reasoning: Partnership of two partners dissolves automatically on death under s.42; no scope for cl.(c) exception.

arguments.claim: Section 42 applies only to partnerships consisting of more than two partners.

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the question turns upon s. 42 of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932  Act 9 of 1932 . the material,part of which reads Subject to contract between the partners a firm is dissolv- ed by the death of a partner. While for the appellant the leaned Attorney General contended that s. 42 applied only to a partnership consisting of more than two partners,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ovisions of the partnership The question is whether on the death of Nandlal his heirs, i.e., the members of his branch of the family, automatically be

arguments.court_reasoning: Agrees firm dissolves on death in two-partner case; cl.(c) applies to more than two partners.

arguments.claim: Section 42 does not impose limitation to more than two partners and applies equally to two-partner firm; contract in cl.3 binds surviving partner and heir is automatically inducted; supported by s.31.

anchor.surface_text: for the respondent Mr. Karkhanis argued that the section did not impose any such limitation and that on its terms it equally applied to a partnership comprising only two partners. It was argued that the contract mentioned in the over-riding clause was a contract between the partners... This conclusion the argument proceeded was also supported by s. 31 of the Partnership Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ovisions of the partnership The question is whether on the death of Nandlal his heirs, i.e., the members of his branch of the family, automatically be

arguments.court_reasoning: Partnership arises from contract not status; s.42(c) for >2 partners; s.31 presupposes subsisting firm.

arguments.claim: Partnership between Nandlal and Bachhulal dissolved on death of Nandlal on December 9, 1945 under s.42 Partnership Act.

anchor.surface_text: rtnership and either the legal heir or the nominee of the deceased partner shall take his place... The result of the discussion is that the partnership between Nandlal and Bachhulal came to an end on the death of Nandlal on December 9, 1945.

arguments.claim: Firm dissolved on death even with cl.3 as it cannot override basic principle that partnership is contractual not by status; cl.(c) s.42 inapplicable to two-partner firm.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 of the said Act says that the relation of partnership arises from contract and not from status. The fundamental principle of partnership, therefore, is that the relation of partnership arises out of contract and not out of status.

arguments.claim: S.31 inapplicable after dissolution as no subsisting partnership to introduce new partner.

anchor.surface_text: That section only recognizes the validity of a contract between the partners to introduce a third party without the consent of all the existing partners it presupposes the subsistence of a partnership it does not apply to a partnership of two partners which is dissolved by the death of one of them

arguments.claim: Allahabad HC in Mt. Sughra v. Babu and Madras HC in Narayanan v. Umayal support dissolution on death in two-partner firm.

anchor.surface_text: Agarwala, J., neatly stated the principle thus In the case of a partnership consisting of only two partners, no partnership remains on the death of one of them... This view accords with that expressed by us earlier. In Narayanan v. Umayal 4 .

arguments.claim: Widow cannot be karta of joint Hindu family as coparcenership necessary for managership.

anchor.surface_text: One is whether the widow of Nandlal could under Hindu law be a karta of the joint Hindu family consisting of three widows and two minors... The view expressed by the Madras High Court is in accordance with well settled principles of Hindu law

arguments.claim: Joint Hindu family cannot be partner but karta can enter partnership representing family.

anchor.surface_text: Another principle which is also equally well settled may be noticed. A joint Hindu family as such cannot be a partner in a firm, but it may, through its karta enter into a valid partnership

arguments.claim: No new partnership after Nandlal's death with Banarsibai or guardians as no deed, no accounts mention, conduct inconsistent.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly no fresh partnership deed was executed between Banarsibai... The accounts only establish that Bachhulal was doing the business... Banarsibais name was not found in the accounts.

arguments.court_reasoning: Evidence shows Bachhulal carried on alone; later deeds exclude her.

arguments.claim: Partnership existed from December 13, 1949 when Venkatlal attained majority, representing his family with Bachhulal.

anchor.surface_text: But, Venkatlal became a major on December 13, 1949... After Venkatlal became a major, there was no obstacle in his representing his branch of the family, in the partnership.

arguments.court_reasoning: Conceded in HC; application signed by both.

arguments.claim: Assessee was firm for AY 1950-51 within s.16(1)(b) IT Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we set aside that part of the finding of the High Court holding that the partnership business was carried on by the representatives of the two families after the death of Nandlal, but confirm the finding to the extent that such a partnership came into existence only after December 13, 1949.

arguments.claim: Partnership can be inferred from conduct between representatives of two families.

anchor.surface_text: It is not disputed that partnership between the representatives of two families can be inferred from conduct. Doubtless the accounts produced before the income-tax authorities disclosed that Bachhulal was

arguments.court_response: No name of Banarsibai in accounts; conduct inconsistent (applied for guardians).

arguments.claim: Tribunal erred in record and omitted relevant material.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the order of the Appellate Tribunal is illegal on account of the Tribunal having committed an error of record and having omitted to consider the relevant material in the case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: pt the view of the Allahabad and Madras High Courts and reject the view expressed by Nagpur and Calcutta High Courts, The result of the discussion is

arguments.court_reasoning: Tribunal misdirected in concluding no partnership.

holdings.text: the partnership between Nandlal and Bachhulal came to an end on the death of Nandlal on December 9, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: rtnership and either the legal heir or the nominee of the deceased partner shall take his plac

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 42(c) of Partnership Act applies even to two-partner firm causing automatic dissolution on death; cl.3 ineffective as partnership arises from contract not status (s.5); s.31 inapplicable post-dissolution; follows Allahabad and Madras HCs over Nagpur/Calcutta.

holdings.text: We are clearly of the opinion that the Madras view is correct.

anchor.surface_text: The view expressed by the Madras High Court is in accordance with well settled principles of Hindu law, while that expressed by the Nagpur High Court is in direct conflict with them. We are clearly of the opinion that the Madras view is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Coparcenership prerequisite for karta/managership; widow not coparcener hence ineligible; prefers Madras/Orissa HCs over Nagpur/Calcutta.

holdings.text: It must, therefore, be held that the Court guardians did not enter into a partnership with Bachhulal.

anchor.surface_text: The conflicting version given by the assessee in regard to person or persons who actually represented the family in the partnership in itself indicates the falsity of the present version. It must, therefore, be held that the Court guardians did not enter into a partnership with Bachhulal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No partnership deed, no mention of Banarsibai/guardians in accounts or documents; conduct inconsistent (application for guardians, later deeds exclude them); evidence insufficient.

holdings.text: from December 13, 1949, the business was carried on in partnership between Venkatlal, representing his branch of the family, and Bachhulal, representing his branch of the family.

anchor.surface_text: After Venkatlal became a major, there was no obstacle in his representing his branch of the family, in the partnership.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Venkatlal attained majority allowing him to represent family as karta; application for registration signed by both; conceded by respondent in HC.

holdings.text: For the assessment year 1950-51 the status of the assessee was that of a firm within the meaning of s. 16(1)(b) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we set aside that part of the finding of the High Court holding that the partnership business was carried on by the representatives of the two families after the death of Nandlal, but confirm the finding to the extent that such a partnership came into existence only after December 13, 1949.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partnership existed from Dec 13, 1949 covering AY 1950-51; applies s.16(1)(b) to facts of karta-represented firm.

holdings.text: The Tribunal misdirected itself in law in reaching the conclusion that the parties could not be regarded as partners.

anchor.surface_text: In this view, we answer the two questions referred to the High Court as under For the assessment year 1950-51 the status of the, assessee was that of a firm within the meaning of s. 16 1 b of the Income-tax Act, 1922. The Tribunal misdirected itself in law in reaching the conclusion that the parties could not be regarded as partners.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tribunal erred in finding no partnership despite evidence of post-1949 partnership.

precedents.citation: Lal Ram Kumar v. Kishori Lal 1

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Allahabad High Court in Lal Ram Kumar v. Kishori Lal 1 is number of any practical help to decide the present case,. There. from the companyduct of the surviving partner and the heirs of the deceased partner after the death of the said partner, the companytract between the original partners that the partnership should number be dissolved on the death of any of them was inferred.

precedents.case_name: Lal Ram Kumar v. Kishori Lal
precedents.cited_proposition: contract between original partners that partnership should not be dissolved on death inferred from conduct of surviving partner and heirs after death

precedents.citation: Chainkarcin Sidhakaran Oswal v Radhakisan Vishwnath Dixit 2

anchor.surface_text: The same criticism applies to the decision of the Nagpur High Court in Chainkarcin Sidhakaran Oswal v Radhakisan Vishwnath Dixit 2 . This question was directly raised and clearly answered by a Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court in Mt. Sughra v. Babu 3  against the legality of such a term of a companytract of partnership companysisting of only two partners.

precedents.case_name: Chainkarcin Sidhakaran Oswal v Radhakisan Vishwnath Dixit
precedents.cited_proposition: partnership clause preventing dissolution on death in two-partner firm

anchor.surface_text: This question was directly raised and clearly answered by a Division Bench of the Allahabad High Court in Mt. Sughra v. Babu 3  against the legality of such a term of a companytract of partnership companysisting of only two partners. Agarwala, J., neatly stated the principle thus In the case of a partnership companysisting of only two partners,

precedents.cited_proposition: in case of partnership consisting of only two partners no partnership remains on death of one and cannot continue by contract; partnership arises from contract not status; no heir becomes partner without consent
precedents.cited_holding: In the case of a partnership companysisting of only two partners, numberpartnership remains on the death of one of them and, therefore, it is a companytradiction in terms to say that there can be a companytract between two partners to the effect that on the death of one of them the partnership will number be dissolved but will companytinue Partnership is number a matter of status, it is a matter of companytract. No heir can be said to become a partner with another person without his own companysent, express or implied.

anchor.surface_text: This view accords with that expressed by us earlier. In Narayanan v. Umayal 4 . Ramachandra lyer J., as he then was, said much to the same effect when he observed thus if one of the partners died, there will number be any partnership existing to which the legal representatives of the deceased partner companyld be taken in.

precedents.cited_proposition: on death of one of two partners, no partnership survives for legal representatives to join; new partnership if they join later
precedents.cited_holding: if one of the partners died, there will number be any partnership existing to which the legal representatives of the deceased partner companyld be taken in. In such a case the partnership would companye to an end by the death of one of the two partners, and if the legal representatives of the deceased partner joins in the business later, it should be referable to a new partnership between therein.

precedents.citation: Hansraj Manot v. Messrs. Gorak Nath Pandey 5

anchor.surface_text: But Chatterjee J., in Hansraj Manot v. Messrs. Gorak Nath Pandey 5  struck a different numbere. His reasons for the companytrary view are expressed thus Here the companytract that has been referred to s the companytract between the two partners Gorak Nath and Champalal Therefore, it cannot be said that the companytract ceased to have effect because a partner died.

precedents.case_name: Hansraj Manot v. Messrs. Gorak Nath Pandey
precedents.cited_proposition: original contract between two partners binds heirs automatically on death without new contract or interregnum
precedents.cited_holding: the heirs become partners automatically without any agreement between the original Partners by virtue of the original agreement between the Partners while they were surviving. there is numberquestion of interregnums. As soon as the death occurs the right of somebody else occurs.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax, C. P. Berar v. Seth Laxmi Narayan Raghunathdas 1

anchor.surface_text: The Nagpur High Court held that a widow companyld be a karta see Commissioner of Income-tax, C. P. Berar v. precedents.cited_proposition: widow could be a karta of joint Hindu family

precedents.cited_proposition: widow could be a karta of joint Hindu family

precedents.citation: Sushila Devi Rampurla v. Income-tax Officer 2

anchor.surface_text: The Calcutta High Court expressed the view that where the male members are minors and their natural guardian is the mother, the mother can represent the Hindu undivided family for the purpose of assessment and recovery of taxes under the Income-tax Act see Sushila Devi Rampurla v. Income-tax Officer 2  and  3   1959  38 I.T.R. 316.

precedents.case_name: Sushila Devi Rampurla v. Income-tax Officer
precedents.cited_proposition: where male members minors, mother as natural guardian can represent HUF for income-tax assessment and recovery

precedents.citation: Sm. Champa Kumari Singhi v. Additional Member, Board of Revenue, West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Sushila Devi Rampurla v. Income-tax Officer 2  and  3   1959  38 I.T.R. 316. Sm. Champa Kumari Singhi v. Additional Member, Board of Revenue, West Bengal 1  The said two decisions did number recognize the widow as a karta of the family, but treated her as the guardian of the minors for the purpose of income- tax assessment.

precedents.case_name: Sm. Champa Kumari Singhi v. Additional Member, Board of Revenue, West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: mother as guardian of minors can represent HUF for income-tax purposes

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the Orissa High Court in Budhi Jena v. Dhobai Naik 2  followed the decision of the Madras High Court in M.N. Radha Ammal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2  wherein Satyanarayana Rao J., observed The right to become a manager depends upon the fundamental fact that the person on whom the right devolved was a companyartner of the joint family

precedents.cited_proposition: coparcenership necessary for managership of joint Hindu family; widow not coparcener hence not manager

precedents.citation: M.N. Radha Ammal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2

anchor.surface_text: followed the decision of the Madras High Court in M.N. Radha Ammal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2  wherein Satyanarayana Rao J., observed The right to become a manager depends upon the fundamental fact that the person on whom the right devolved was a companyartner of the joint family Further, the right is companyfined to the male members of the family as the female members were number treated as companyartner though they may be members of the joint family.

precedents.case_name: M.N. Radha Ammal v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: coparcenership is necessary qualification for managership; widow not coparcener hence cannot be manager/karta even with minor sons
precedents.cited_holding: The right to become a manager depends upon the fundamental fact that the person on whom the right devolved was a companyartner of the joint family... Coparcenership is a necessary qualification for managership of a joint Hindu family... It will be revolutionary of all accepted principles of Hindu law to suppose that the senior most female member of a joint Hindu family... companyld be the manager of the family She would be the guardian of her minor sons till the eldest of them attains majority but she would number be the manager of the joint family for she is number a companyartner.

precedents.citation: Kshetra Mohan Sanyasi Charan Sadhukhan v. C.E.P.T. 1

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Kshetra  1   1961  46 T.T.R. 81  2  A.I.R. 1956 Orissa 6.  3   1950  18 I.T.R. 225, 230, 232, 233. Mohan Sanyasi Charan Sadhukhan v. C.E.P.T.  1  pointed out that when two kartas of different families companystituted a partnership the other members of the families did number become partners, though the karta might be accountable to them.

precedents.case_name: Kshetra Mohan Sanyasi Charan Sadhukhan v. C.E.P.T.
precedents.cited_proposition: joint Hindu family as such cannot be partner in firm but karta may enter partnership; other family members not partners

In this view, we answer the two questions referred to the High Court as under For the assessment year 1950-51 the status of the, assessee was that of a firm within the meaning of s. 16 1 b of the Income-tax Act, 1922. The Tribunal misdirected itself in law in reaching the conclusion that the parties could not be regarded as partners.
In the result the appeals are dismissed.
